tn.text: This word is used here to mark a new part of the story.
"there was a famine" or "there was another famine"
You can state explicitly the land to which this refers. AT: "in the land where Isaac and his family lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: that had been in the days of Abraham
tn.text: The phrase "in the days" means the time when Abraham lived. AT: "that had happened during Abraham's life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Yahweh begins to speak to Isaac.
"appeared to Isaac"

tn.ref: Do not go down to Egypt
tn.text: It was common to speak of leaving the promised land as "going down" to another place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: for to you and to your descendants, I will give all these lands
tn.text: "for I will give all these lands to you and your descendants"

tn.ref: I will fulfill the oath that I swore to Abraham your father
tn.text: "I will do what I promised Abraham your father I would do"
Yahweh continues speaking to Isaac.
"I will cause you to have very many descendants."

This speaks about the number of Isaac's descendants as if they were the same as the number of stars. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:22:15|22:17]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This refers to everything we see above the earth, including the sun, moon, and stars.

tn.ref: all the nations of the earth will be blessed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will bless all the nations of the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Abraham obeyed my voice and kept my instructions, my commandments, my statutes, and my laws
tn.text: The phrases "obeyed my voice" and "kept my instructions, my commandments, my statutes, and my laws" mean basically the same thing. AT: "Abraham obeyed me and did everything I commanded him to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here "voice" stands for Yahweh. AT: "obeyed me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Only Isaac is mentioned because he is the leader of the family, but his whole family was with him. AT: "So Isaac and his family settled in Gerar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "fear" refers to the unpleasant feeling a person has when there is a threat of harm to himself or others. "He was afraid to say"
"in order to take Rebekah"
The word "behold" shows that what Abimelech saw surprised him. AT: "And he was surprised to see that Isaac"
Possible meanings are 1) he was touching her the way a husband touches his wife or 2) he was laughing and talking with her the way a husband talks with his wife.
Abimelech probably sent someone to tell Isaac that Abimelech wanted to see him. AT: "Abimelech sent someone to bring Isaac to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Why did you say, 'She is my sister'?
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "Why did you say that she is your sister?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
"so he could take her"

tn.ref: What is this you have done to us?
tn.text: Abimelech used this question to scold Isaac. AT: "You should not have done this to us!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: you would have brought guilt upon us
tn.text: This speaks about causing someone to be guilty as if "guilt" were an object that is placed on someone. AT: "you would have caused us to be guilty of taking a man's wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "us" refers to Abimelech and his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
Here "touches" means to touch in a harmful way. AT: "Whoever harms this man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: will surely be put to death
tn.text: Abimelech may have intended to tell someone to kill anyone who might harm Isaac or Rebekah. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will put him to death" or "I will order my men to kill him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This begins a new part of the story. It changes from telling about Isaac calling Rebekah his sister, and it starts to tell about how Isaac became very rich and the Philistines were jealous of him.
"in Gerar"
This means "one hundred times as much as he planted." It can be translated more generally as "a very large crop" (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"Isaac became rich" or "He became rich"

tn.ref: and grew more and more until he became very great
tn.text: "and he gained more and more until he became very wealthy"
This may also include goats. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "household" stands for workers or servants. AT: "many servants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"The Philistines were jealous of him"

Here this word does not mean "at this moment." It is indicating where the action in the story begins. It can be translated with the connecting word "So" to show that this is a result of what happened in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:26:12|26:12-13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])

tn.ref: in the days of Abraham his father
tn.text: The phrase "in the days of" stands for a person's lifetime. AT: "when Abraham, his father, was living" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Possible meanings are 1) this is another action to force Isaac and his people to leave. AT: "Then Abimelech said" or "Finally Abimelech said" or 2) Abimelech made this decision because he saw that his people were jealous and acting in a hostile way towards Isaac. AT: "Therefore Abimelech said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])
"much stronger than we are"
Only Isaac is mentioned because he is the leader, but his family and servants went with him. AT: "So Isaac and his household left" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "Isaac" stands for Isaac and his servants. AT: "Isaac and his servants dug out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"which Abraham's servants had dug"

tn.ref: in the days of Abraham his father
tn.text: The phrase "in the days of" stands for a person's lifetime. AT: "when Abraham, his father, was living." See how this was translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:26:15|26:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: The Philistines had stopped them up
tn.text: This was the reason that Isaac dug them out. Possible ways to translate this are: 1) Since this happened first, this sentence can come before the sentence about Isaac digging them out, as in the UDB. or 2) This sentence can start with "Isaac did this because the Philistines had stopped them up." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_events]])
"had filled them with earth"

This phrase refers to a natural spring they uncovered when they were digging a new well. It provided a continuous flow of fresh drinking water. AT: "fresh water" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"men who tended the herds"
Here "ours" refers to the herdsmen of Gerar. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
Translators may also add a footnote that says "The name Esek means 'quarrel' or 'argue.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"Then Isaac's servants dug" (UDB)
"the herdsmen of Gerar argued with Isaac's herdsmen"
"so Isaac gave it"
Translators may add a footnote that says "The name Sitnah means 'oppose' or 'accuse.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Translators may add a footnote that says "The name Rehoboth means 'make room for' or 'empty place.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Isaac was speaking about himself and his household.

tn.ref: Isaac went up from there to Beersheba
tn.text: Here "went up" is probably a reference to going north. Say that he departed in the most natural way for your language. AT: "Isaac left there and went to Beersheba"
"will cause your descendants to increase greatly" or "will cause your descendants to be very many"
"for my servant Abraham" or you can make the full meaning explicit. AT: "because I promised my servant Abraham that I would do this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
You can make explicit why Isaac built an altar. AT: "Isaac built an altar there to sacrifice to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: called on the name of Yahweh
tn.text: To "call on" means to pray or to worship. Here "name" stands for Yahweh. AT: "prayed to Yahweh" or "worshiped Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"went to Isaac"
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Possible meanings are 1) "Abimelech's friend" or 2) "Abimelech's advisor."
This is the name of a man. See how you translated his name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:21:22|21:22]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This refers to Abimelech, Ahuzzath, and Phicol. One of them spoke and the other two agreed with what he said. It does not mean they all spoke at the same time. AT: "one of them said"
"We know" or "We are certain"

tn.ref: So let us make a covenant
tn.text: "So we want to make a covenant"

tn.ref: and as we have treated you well
tn.text: This can also be translated as the beginning of a new sentence. "We have done only good to you"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh has blessed you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Isaac made a feast for them, and they ate and drank
tn.text: Eating a meal together was a part of making a covenant with one another. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "them" refers to "Abimelech, Ahuzzath, and Phicol"
Here "they" refers to Isaac, Abimelech, Ahuzzath, and Phicol. AT: "they all ate" (UDB)
"They awoke early"
"So he called the well Shibah." Translators may add a footnote that says "The name Shibah sounds like the word that means 'oath.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Translators may add a footnote saying "Beersheba can mean either "well of the oath" or "well of seven." (See note on [[:en:bible:notes:gen:21:31|21:32]])
Most of Genesis 26 was about Isaac. These verses are about his older son Esau.
"40" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"he married." You can state explicitly that he married two women. AT: "he took two wives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These are the names of Esau's wives. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"the descendant of Heth" or "a descendant of Heth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: They brought sorrow to Isaac and Rebekah
tn.text: Here "they" refers to Judith and Basemath. To make someone sorrowful or miserable is spoken of as if "sorrow" were an object that a person could bring to another person. AT: "They made Isaac and Rebekah sorrowful" or "Isaac and Rebekah were miserable because of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
